revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1) ([[User:Balon Greyjoy|Balon Greyjoy]])
revision.text:
'''Adolf Gottlieb (also: Gottlob) Fiedler''' (1771 – 12 August 1850) was a [[Germany|German]] entrepreneur in [[Electorate of Saxony|Saxony]] and [[Congress Poland|Poland]].
==Life== Born in [[Dresden]] as the son of Christian Gottlob Fiedler, Adolf was one of the most important cloth producers of Saxony in the beginning of the 19th century. The operational seat of the company was in [[Oederan]] in Saxony. He also had factories in [[Kalisz]] and [[Opatówek]] (both in Poland), [[Wegefarth]], [[Wingendorf]], [[Falkenau]] and [[Berthelsdorf]] (all in Saxony). He followed other cloth producers to eastern regions at the time of the German [[industrial revolution]] because of lower salaries and large loans offered by the Polish government. The German investments in Poland were followed by experienced Saxon and [[Bohemia]]n specialists to run the factories. An additional reason was local water power.
From 1824-1826 Fiedler established one of the biggest cloth mills in Congress Poland. He employed around 600 workers in his Polish mill in Opatówek. The products of Fiedler were well known for their quality and won several international prizes.
Fiedler was also [[mayor]] of Oederan. He had one son, Eduard Magnus and he died in Dresden. ==See also== * [[Textile manufacture during the Industrial Revolution]]
==References== * Rudolf Forberger: "Industrielle Revolution in Sachsen 1800-1861", Akademie-Verlag, Berlin 1982 Band 1/2 Page 147-150 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060721043102/http://www.biblioteka.opatowek.pl/003/gmin0003a.html Opatowek Library] {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fiedler, Adolf Gottlieb}} [[Category:1771 births]] [[Category:1850 deaths]] [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:Mayors of places in Saxony]] [[Category:People from Dresden]] [[Category:People from the Electorate of Saxony]]
{{Germany-business-bio-stub}} {{Poland-business-bio-stub}} {{Germany-mayor-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox Politician | honorific-prefix = [[Malay titles|Yang Berbahagia Datuk]] | name = Ahmad Ismail | image = | caption = | birth_date = 1955 | birth_place = | residence = | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[University of Denver]] | parliament = | constituency_MP = | term_start = | term_end = | predecessor = | successor = | office2 = Former chief of [[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]] [[Penang Hill|Bukit Bendera]] ([[Penang Hill]]) | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | constituency2 = | office3 = | term_start3 = | term_end3 = | predecessor3 = | successor3 = | constituency3 = | party = [[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]]-[[Barisan Nasional|BN]] | religion = [[Sunni Islam]] | occupation = Politician | majority = | relations = | spouse = | children = | website = | footnotes = }} [[Malay titles|Datuk]] '''Ahmad bin Ismail''' (born 1955{{cite news|date=10 September 2008 |url=http://www.sun2surf.com/article.cfm?id=25544 |title=Man of controversy |work=Himanshu Bhatt |publisher=[[The Sun (Malaysia)|Sun2Surf]] |accessdate=10 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210152441/http://www.sun2surf.com/article.cfm?id=25544 |archivedate=10 February 2009 }}), is a Malaysian politician and a member of the [[United Malays National Organisation]] (UMNO), serving as the chief of UMNO's [[Penang Hill|Bukit Bendera]] ([[Penang Hill]]) division in the state of [[Penang]]. Ahmad Ismail is known for controversial actions and remarks made in the fields of politics, business and sports, including the latest controversy in which he uttered incendiary remarks about the Chinese community during and after the [[Permatang Pauh by-election, 2008|Permatang Pauh by-election in August 2008]], leading to his suspension by UMNO in September 2008. == Political career == === Accusations of racism === ==== "Chinese as squatters" remark ==== In late August 2008, Ahmad Ismail was highlighted over racist remarks uttered during campaigning in [[Permatang Pauh by-election, 2008|a by-election]] in [[Permatang Pauh]] that primarily pitted [[Barisan Nasional]] candidate Arif Shah Omar Shah (UMNO) against [[Pakatan Rakyat]] candidate [[Anwar Ibrahim]] (PKR) for the [[Permatang Pauh]] parliamentary seat. On 25 August 2008 local Chinese daily ''[[Sin Chew Daily]]'' reported a speech made by Ahmad Ismail on the evening of 23 August 2008 at [[Kampung Pelet]] to campaign for Arif Shah, in which he allegedly stated [[Malaysian Chinese]] were "immigrants" and "squatters", and could not have equal rights.{{cite news|date=9 September 2008 | url=http://in.news.yahoo.com/137/20080910/362/twl-malaysia-ruling-party-suspends-offic_1.html| title=Malaysia ruling party suspends official in race row | agency=[[Reuters]] | publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] | accessdate=10 September 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In a 6 September statement by Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi, Ahmad was quoted that he merely uttered the remark based on historical facts and claimed it was not a racist statement as reported by ''Sin Chew Daily'', accusing the paper of misinterpreting him.{{cite news | date=6 September 2008 | url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/9/6/nation/20080906213834 | title=PM: Don't create tension among races | work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] | accessdate=10 October 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604005213/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2008%2F9%2F6%2Fnation%2F20080906213834 | archive-date=4 June 2011 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} Despite criticism of his remark in the by-election and expressing regret that it resulted in controversy, Ahmad remained defiant and refused to apologise. In a further outburst during a press conference on 8 September, Ahmad seditiously warned the Chinese community not to seek political power:{{cite news|date=9 September 2008 |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20080909/wl_asia_afp/malaysiapoliticsrace_080909145027| title=Malaysia faces race row over 'anti-Chinese' comments | agency = [[Agence France-Presse]] | publisher = [[Yahoo! News]] | accessdate=10 September 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news | date = 9 September 2008 | url = http://news.my.msn.com/regional/article.aspx?cp-documentid=1667156 | title = Malaysia faces race row over 'anti-Chinese' comments | agency = [[Agence France-Presse]] | publisher = [[MSN|MSN Malaysia News]] | accessdate = 10 October 2008 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080917012749/http://news.my.msn.com/regional/article.aspx?cp-documentid=1667156 | archive-date = 17 September 2008 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}{{cite news|date = 9 September 2008 |url = http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/SE%2BAsia/Story/STIStory_276781.html | title = Official to be punished | work = [[The Straits Times]] | accessdate=10 October 2008}}
"The patience of the Malays and Muslims has a limit. Do not push us to the wall, as when we turn back we will be forced to push the Chinese in the interests of our own survival [...] The Chinese should not try to be like the [[Jews]] in [[United States|America]]. It is not enough they control the economy, now they want political control."
Following a meeting with Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi on 9 September,{{cite news|date = 9 September 2008 |url = http://www.utusan.com.my/utusan/arkib.asp?y=2008&dt=0909&pub=utusan_malaysia&sec=terkini&pg=bt_10.htm&arc=hive |language=Malay| title = Ahmad Ismail jumpa PM di Putrajaya | publisher = [[Utusan Malaysia]] | quote = ''Ketua UMNO Bahagian Bukit Bendera, Datuk Ahmad Ismail tiba di pejabat Perdana Menteri di sini pukul 12.50 tengah hari ini untuk mengadakan pertemuan dengan Datuk Seri Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. [...] Beliau dipanggil oleh Perdana Menteri untuk memberi penjelasan mengenai tindak-tanduknya selepas satu ucapannya berhubung kedudukan orang Cina sebelum merdeka menimbulkan keretakan politik Barisan Nasional (BN).''| accessdate=10 October 2008}} Ahmad would later be quoted in stating Malays were "frustrated" and that Malay "dignity" was at stake, remaining convinced that he is more nationalistic defending the Malays rather than being racist:
"Half the Chinese say I'm a racist but most Malays say I'm a nationalist defending my race [...] What I see now is a rise of the Malay people, and I feel we should capitalise on the strength, the support we get from the Malay people... I know they are with me."
==== Reaction to His Comments ==== Revelations of Ahmad Ismail's comments during and after the by-election drew widespread criticism predominantly from the Chinese community. On 27 August, the youth wing of the [[Malaysian Chinese Association]] (MCA) demanded an apology from Ahmad, with secretary-general [[Wee Ka Siong]] stating Ahmad had angered the Chinese as well as other non-Malay communities; Wee had also received numerous complaints from the Chinese community in the past two days.{{cite news | date = 9 September 2008 | url = http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/8/27/nation/20080827152034 | title = MCA Youth want apology from Umno chief for racist statement | author = Sim Leoi Leoi | work = [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] | accessdate = 10 October 2008 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110604005227/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2008%2F8%2F27%2Fnation%2F20080827152034 | archive-date = 4 June 2011 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} On 9 September, [[Parti Gerakan Rakyat Malaysia|Gerakan]] president [[Koh Tsu Koon]] announced Penang Gerakan has dissociated itself from UMNO's Penang branch, holding leaders of UMNO Penang accountable for failing to condemn Ahmad's conduct:{{cite news|date = 9 September 2008 |url = http://www.malaysiatoday.com/Latest-News/we-no-longer-want-to-be-associated-with-penang-umno-dr-koh.html | title = We no longer want to be associated with Penang Umno – Dr Koh | work = Zen | publisher = [[Malaysia Today]] | accessdate = 10 October 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}
"We no longer want to be associated with Penang UMNO. We condemned the statement and irresponsible behaviour by Ahmad and his supporters. We are also extremely disappointed and saddened by the fact that many Penang UMNO leaders were present and condoned such irresponsible and insensitive statement and behaviour. He had twisted and turned a personal mistake into a conflict and crisis among BN component parties and the communities."
Views among members of UMNO were less conclusive. Following revelations of Ahmad's comments in the by-election, Prime Minister Abdullah Badawi stated party leaders expressed "regret and anger" over Ahmad Ismail's remark, as UMNO considered actions to be taken against Ahmad. Former Law Minister [[Mohamed Nazri Abdul Aziz]] and former Prime Minister [[Mahathir bin Mohamad|Mahathir Mohammad]] voiced similar views that Ahmad Ismail should be held accountable for his remarks and issue an apology.{{cite news |date = 6 September 2008 |url = http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/9/6/nation/20080906143533 |language = Malay |title = No harm in saying sorry: Nazri |author = V. P. Sujata |work = [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |accessdate = 10 October 2008 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110604005240/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2008%2F9%2F6%2Fnation%2F20080906143533 |archive-date = 4 June 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }} In a 6 September report published by ''[[Utusan Malaysia]]'', [[Muhammad Muhammad Taib]] reiterated Ahamd's defence, asking the public, especially politicians, not to put forward baseless accusations against Ahmad, claiming his remarks could merely be used in the context of history rather than politics.{{cite news|date = 6 September 2008 |url = http://beritamalaysiakini.wordpress.com/2008/09/06/jangan-buat-tuduhan-melulu-terhadap-ahmad-kata-muhammad-taib-utusan/ | title = Jangan buat tuduhan melulu terhadap Ahmad, kata Muhammad Taib – Utusan | work = [[Utusan Malaysia]] | publisher = Berita Malaysia Kini | accessdate = 10 October 2008}} ==== Suspension from UMNO ==== In 2008, UMNO imposed a suspension on Ahmad for three years.{{cite news| url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsindex.php?id=358360|title=Ahmad Accepts Umno Supreme Council's Decision|date=10 September 2008 |agency=Bernama|accessdate=10 September 2008}} === Reactions to His Suspension === However stronger action than had been expected in a bid to soothe growing anger from the Chinese community and among parties in [[Barisan Nasional]] ruling coalition.{{cite news|date=9 September 2008 |url=http://in.news.yahoo.com/137/20080910/362/twl-malaysia-ruling-party-suspends-offic_1.html |title=Malaysia ruling party suspends official in race row |publisher=Reuters via Yahoo! News }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On 12 September 2008 Sin Chew Daily reporter Tan Hoon Cheng who reported the speech made by Ahmad Ismail, had been arrested under the [[Internal Security Act (Malaysia)|Internal Security Act]] at 8.30pm at her home in Bukit Mertajam, Penang. {{cite news|date=13 September 2008| title=Sin Chew reporter released after one day under ISA detention |url=http://www.thenutgraph.com/sin-chew-reporter-released-after-one-day-under-isa-detention|publisher=The Nut Graph}}{{cite news|date=12 September 2008| title=Sin Chew Reporter Picked Up Under ISA|url=http://www.mysinchew.com/node/16188|publisher=Sin Chew}} The MCA, a component party of the Barisan National, has expressed shock that Ahmad Ismail, who made racist remarks has not been taken to task but reporter Tan Hoon Cheng, who wrote about the incident, has been arrested instead.{{cite news|accessdate=28 January 2010|title=Press statement by MCA's Datuk Dr Ng Yen Yen|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/8938-media-statement-by-wanita-mca-chairman-and-minister-of-womenfamily-and-comminity-development-in-response-to-the-isa-arrests-of-sin-chew-reporter-tan-hoon-cheng|publisher=The Malaysian Insider|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323155603/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/8938-media-statement-by-wanita-mca-chairman-and-minister-of-womenfamily-and-comminity-development-in-response-to-the-isa-arrests-of-sin-chew-reporter-tan-hoon-cheng|archive-date=23 March 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} "The perpetrator who vowed to conduct a nationwide roadshow on his remarks without any remorse is still at large," MCA vice-president Datuk Ong Tee Keat said.{{cite news|date=14 September 2008|title=Sin Chew reporter goes home a day after ISA arrest|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?sec=nation&file=/2008/9/14/nation/2025921|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|access-date=5 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011095346/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?sec=nation&file=%2F2008%2F9%2F14%2Fnation%2F2025921|archive-date=11 October 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} == Business == In 1995, Peninsular Metroworks {{h:title|Private Limited|Sdn Bhd|}} was founded with Ahmad Ismail as its executive chairman. The company was a special purpose vehicle, intended to receive concession to develop the [[Penang Outer Ring Road]] (PORR), a project which was subsequently delayed by the federal government in 2008 following the [[Malaysian general election, 2008|2008 general election]]. Additionally, a majority stake in Peninsular Metroworks was indirectly linked to Ahmad Ismail: A 55% stake in the company was held in its early years by Nadi Senandung Sdn Bhd, which Ahmad was the director of; the remaining 45% was held by Setegap Bhd and Kumpulan Pinang Holdings Sdn Bhd, the latter a full subsidiary of Yayasan Bumiputra Pulau Pinang {{h:title|Limited|Bhd|}}. Ahmad Ismail was also the director of Popular Profile Sdn Bhd, which the Penang Development Corporation believed had wrongfully taken and kept RM500,000 from the state in a botched land transaction for [[Bukit Minyak]] in 1998, before winding up in 2005; Ahmad was believed to have cut links with the company in 1998.{{cite news |date = 3 September 2008 |url = http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/9/3/nation/20080903173006 |title = PDC lodges report against Ahmad and former company |author = Andrea Filmer |work = [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |accessdate = 10 October 2008 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110604005259/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2008%2F9%2F3%2Fnation%2F20080903173006 |archive-date = 4 June 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }} A police report was lodged by Penang Development Corporation on 3 September 2008. Crossback Arowana Farm at Bukit Merah Perak is Ahmad's latest business venture. He is a major shareholder for this golden arowana breeding farm and most of his pricey arowanas are exported to Mainland China. == Sports == In addition to interests in politics and business, Ahmad Ismail was also the president of the Malaysian Sepak Takraw Association. During the [[2007 Southeast Asian Games]] in [[Korat]], [[Thailand]], Ahmad led the pullout of Malaysia's [[sepak takraw]] team at the last minute. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahmad, Ismail}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Anti-Chinese sentiment in Asia]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Malay descent]] [[Category:Malaysian businesspeople]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Indian descent]] [[Category:Malaysian Muslims]] [[Category:People from Penang]] [[Category:Political scandals in Malaysia]] [[Category:Members of the Dewan Negara]]

'''Alfredo "Al" S. Panlilio''' is a Filipino businessman. He is the current Senior Vice President and head of customer retail services, corporate marketing and communications of the [[MERALCO|Manila Electric Company]] (MERALCO)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thestandard.com.ph/business/209155/meralco-expects-16-sales-volume-to-expand-7-.html|title=Meralco expects ’16 sales volume to expand 7%|publisher=[[Manila Standard]]|last=Flores|first=Alena Mae S.|date=June 26, 2016|accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name="panlilio">{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/business-life/2016/02/01/1548247/create-culture-customer-centricity-greater-success|title=Create ‘culture of customer-centricity’ for greater success|publisher=[[The Philippine Star]]|last=Flores|first=Wilson Lee|date=February 1, 2016|accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> and the team governor of the [[Meralco Bolts]] basketball team, currently playing in the [[Philippine Basketball Association]] (PBA).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pba.inquirer.net/teams/meralco-bolts|title=Meralco Bolts|publisher=PBA|accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref> He was also a former Senior Vice President of MERALCO's sister company [[PLDT]] from 1999 to 2010. He is also a president of the MVP Sports Foundation.<ref name="panlilio"/>
He was elected as the new president of the [[Samahang Basketbol ng Pilipinas]] (SBP), on its election for its new set of board of directors of the basketball national sports association on August 8, 2016. He replaced [[Manuel V. Pangilinan]], who served as the president since it was formed in 2007 and was recognized by the [[FIBA]] as the solely recognized governing body for basketball in the Philippines, replacing the [[Basketball Association of the Philippines]] (BAP).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spin.ph/basketball/news/manny-v-pangilinan-era-ends-as-samahang-basketbol-ng-pilipinas-hold|title=End of an era as Samahang Basketbol ng Pilipinas elects Manny Pangilinan's successor|publisher=[[Sports Interactive Network Philippines]]|last=Ramos|first=Gerry|date=August 7, 2016|accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2016/08/08/1611362/panlilio-new-sbp-chief-gilas-program-continues|title=Panlilio is new SBP chief; Gilas program continues|publisher=[[The Philippine Star]]|last=Beltran|first=Nelson|date=August 8, 2016|accessdate=August 9, 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Panlilio, Al}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:Filipino sports executives and administrators]] [[Category:PLDT people]]

{{Infobox NFL biography | name = Art Rooney | image = Art Rooney.jpg | alt = Candid black and white head-shot photograph of Rooney wearing a white shirt and black-rimmed eyeglasses chewing on an unlit cigar | caption = Image of Rooney from "BELIEVE" posters | position = Owner | birth_date = {{Birth date|1901|1|27|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Coulterville, Pennsylvania]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1988|8|25|1901|1|27|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] | high_school = Duquesne University Prep | college = [[Indiana University of Pennsylvania|Indiana Normal]], [[Georgetown University|Georgetown]] | pastexecutive = * [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] (1933–1988)
Founder, chairman & owner | highlights = As owner: * 4× [[Super Bowl]] champion ([[Super Bowl IX|IX]], [[Super Bowl X|X]], [[Super Bowl XIII|XIII]], [[Super Bowl XIV|XIV]]) * 4× [[AFC Championship Game|AFC champion]] ([[1974–75 NFL playoffs|1974]], [[1975–76 NFL playoffs|1975]], [[1978–79 NFL playoffs|1978]], [[1979–80 NFL playoffs|1979]]) * 2011 [[Pittsburgh Pro Football Hall of Fame]] | HOF = art-rooney }} '''Arthur Joseph Rooney Sr.''' (January 27, 1901 – August 25, 1988), often referred to as "The Chief", was the founding owner of the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], an [[American football]] franchise in the [[National Football League]] (NFL), from 1933 until his death. Rooney is a member of the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]], was an Olympic qualifying boxer, and was part or whole owner in several track sport venues and Pittsburgh area pro teams. He was the first president of the Pittsburgh Steelers from 1933 to 1974, and the first chairman of the team from 1933 to 1988. ==Family history== Rooney's great-grandparents, James and Mary Rooney, were [[Irish Catholic]]s who [[Emigration|emigrated]] from [[Newry]] in [[County Down]], Ireland to Canada during the [[Great Famine (Ireland)|Irish potato famine]] in the 1840s. While living in [[Montreal]], the Rooneys had a son, Arthur (who would become Art Rooney's grandfather). James and Mary later moved to [[Ebbw Vale]], [[Wales]], where the iron industry was flourishing, taking their son Arthur, then 21, with them. This Arthur Rooney married Catherine Regan (who was also Irish Catholic), in Wales, and they had a son, Dan. Two years after Dan Rooney was born, the family moved back to Canada and eventually ended up in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] in 1884. Along the way the family grew to include nine children of which Dan was the second.{{cite book |last1=Rooney |first1=Arthur J. (Jr.) |last2=McHugh |first2=Roy |title=Ruanaidh:The Story of Art Rooney and his clan |year=2008 |publisher=artrooneyjr.com |isbn=978-0-9814760-3-2 |pages=2–5}} Dan Rooney remained in the Pittsburgh area, and eventually opened a saloon in the [[Monongahela Valley]] coal town of [[Coulter, Pennsylvania]] (or Coultersville). This is where Dan Rooney met and wed Margaret "Maggie" Murray, who was the daughter of a coal miner, and where the couple's first son, Arthur Joseph Rooney, was born. Dan and Maggie would eventually settle their family in Pittsburgh's [[North Side (Pittsburgh)|North Side]] in 1913, where they bought a three-story building at the corner of Corey Street and General Robinson Street. Dan operated a cafe and saloon out of the first floor with the family living above. The building was located just a block from [[Exposition Park (Pittsburgh)|Exposition Park]], which had been home to the [[History of the Pittsburgh Pirates#1901–1969|Pittsburgh Pirates]] baseball team until [[1909 Pittsburgh Pirates season|1909]]. ==Education and athletics== Rooney attended St. Peter's Catholic School in Pittsburgh, [[Duquesne University]] Prep School, then several semesters at [[Indiana University of Pennsylvania|Indiana Normal School]] before completing a final year at [[Temple University]] on an athletic scholarship.{{cite news |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/sports/steelers/from-the-pg-archives-rooney-unique-in-pro-football-hall-of-fame-503918/ |work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |first=Vince |last=Johnson |title=From the PG Archives: Rooney Unique in Pro Football Hall of Fame |date=September 30, 2007}} After graduation, he dedicated himself to sports, winning the AAU welterweight belt in 1918 and tried out for the 1920 Olympic Team,[http://www.americanmemorabilia.com/Auction_Item.asp?Auction_ID=56181]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} he played minor league baseball for both the [[Flint Vehicles|Flint, Michigan "Vehicles"]] and the [[Wheeling Stogies|Wheeling, West Virginia "Stogies"]].{{cite web |url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=rooney001art |title=Art Rooney Register Statistics & History – Baseball-Reference.com |publisher=}} In 1925 he served as Wheeling's player-manager and led the [[Middle Atlantic League]] in games, hits, runs, stolen bases and finished 2nd in batting average as his brother Dan Rooney (Wheelings catcher that year) finished 3rd in BA. Art also played halfback for the semi-pro Pittsburgh "Hope Harvey" and "Majestic Radio" clubs which he later took over and renamed the [[J.P. Rooneys]] before purchasing an NFL franchise for $2,500 in 1933. ==Pittsburgh Steelers== {{details|History of the Pittsburgh Steelers}} {{Quote box | quote = The biggest thrill wasn't in winning on Sunday but in meeting the payroll on Monday. | source = 1983 Steelers yearbook {{cite web |url=http://www.pittsburghsteelers.co.uk/steelers/rooneys/page4.htm |title=Art Rooney |publisher=}} | width = 31em | salign =right | title = Art Rooney on the good ole days | quoted = 1 | title_bg = gray | title_fnt = white | bgcolor = lightgray }} Rooney's affiliation with the [[National Football League]] (NFL) began in 1933 when he paid a $2,500 franchise fee to found a club based in the city of Pittsburgh. He had named his new team the "Pirates" which was also the name of the city's long-established [[Major League Baseball]] [[Pittsburgh Pirates|club]] of which Rooney was a fan since a childhood spent in the shadow of the team's stadium. Since the league's inception in 1920, the NFL had wanted a team in Pittsburgh due to the city's already-long history with [[American football|football]] as well as the popularity of the [[Pittsburgh Panthers football]] team, an [[NCAA]] national championship contender during this period. The league was finally able to take advantage of [[Pennsylvania]] relaxing their [[blue laws]] that prior to 1933 prohibited sporting events from taking place on Sundays, when most NFL games take place. In 1936, Rooney won a [[Parlay (gambling)|parlay]] at [[Saratoga Race Course]], which netted him about $160,000. He used the winnings to hire a coach, [[Joe Bach]], give contracts to his players and almost win a championship. The winnings funded the team until 1941 when he sold the franchise to NY playboy Alex Thompson. Thompson wanted to move the franchise to Boston so he could be within a five-hour train ride of his club. At the same time, the Philadelphia Eagles ran into financial problems. Rooney used the funds from the sale of franchise to get a 70% interest in the Eagles, the other 30% held by Rooney friend and future NFL commissioner, Bert Bell. Bell and Rooney agreed to trade places with Thompson. Bell took the role of President of the Steelers that he relinquished to Rooney in 1946 when Bell became Commissioner. Rooney got his good friend and his sister's father in law, Barney McGinley, to buy Bell's shares. Barney's son Jack, Art's brother in law, retained the McGinley interest that passed to his heirs when he died in 2006.{{cite book |last=Tucker |first1=Murray |title=Screamer: The Forgotten Voice of the Pittsburgh Steelers |isbn=978-0595471256 }} {{Quote box | quote =The Rooneys are the finest people, the people I most respect in American sports ownership. I've always felt that way. And there's no reason to change. They are people of integrity and character. The way they put the Steelers together, to hire a man like Chuck Noll, to emphasize the team concept. I have a whole transcendental feeling for the Steelers and the Rooneys and Pittsburgh. | source =— Howard Cosell, October 1982{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qEocAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A2AEAAAAIBAJ&dq=howard%20cosell%20plays%20pittsburgh%20they%20play%20the%20whole%20city&pg=4344,3796544 |title=The Pittsburgh Press – Google News Archive Search |publisher=}} | width = 31em | salign =right | title = Howard Cosell on the Rooneys | quoted = 1 | title_bg = gray | title_fnt = white | bgcolor = lightgray }} Rooney sent shock waves through the NFL by signing [[Byron White|Byron "Whizzer" White]] to a record-breaking $15,000 contract in 1938. This move, however, did not bring the Pirates a winning season, and White left the team for the [[Detroit Lions]] the following year. The club did not have a season above .500 until 1942, the year after they were renamed the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. During World War II, the Steelers had some financial difficulties and were merged with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] [[Steagles|in 1943]] and the [[Chicago Cardinals]] [[Card-Pitt|in 1944]]. After the war, Rooney became team president. He longed to bring an NFL title to [[Pittsburgh]] but was never able to beat the powerhouse teams, like the [[Cleveland Browns]] and [[Green Bay Packers]]. The Steelers also struggled with playing in a city and era where baseball was king and were treated as something of a joke compared to the Pirates. The team also made some questionable personnel calls at the time such as cutting a then-unknown [[Johnny Unitas]] in training camp (Unitas would go on to a [[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] career with the [[Baltimore Colts]]) and trading their [[1965 NFL Draft|first round pick in the 1965 draft]] to the [[Chicago Bears]] (who would draft [[Dick Butkus]] with the pick), among others. Nevertheless, Rooney was popular with owners as a mediator, which would carry over to his son [[Dan Rooney]]. He was the only owner to vote against moving the rights of the [[New York Yanks]] to [[Dallas, Texas]] after the [[1951 NFL season|1951 season]] due to concerns of [[racism]] in the [[Southern United States|South]] at the time.''75 Seasons: The Complete Story of the National Football League'', pg. 103 (Ultimately, the [[Dallas Texans (NFL)|Dallas Texans]] failed after one year, and the rights were moved to [[Baltimore]], where the team became the [[Baltimore Colts]]. [[Indianapolis Colts|The team]] now [[Baltimore Colts relocation to Indianapolis|plays in Indianapolis]].) In 1963, along with Bears owner [[George Halas]], Rooney was one of two owners to vote for the [[1925 NFL Championship controversy|1925 NFL Championship]] to be reinstated to the long-defunct [[Pottsville Maroons]]. ==Pittsburgh Penguins== As a pillar of the community in many aspects, Rooney was asked to lend his considerable influence in the city's bid to reclaim a [[National Hockey League|NHL]] franchise during the league's expansion in 1967. Although Pittsburgh enjoyed championship hockey with the professional but "minor league" [[Pittsburgh Hornets]] since its NHL franchise (the [[Pittsburgh Pirates (NHL)|Pirates hockey team]]) disbanded in 1930 from the effects of the [[Great Depression]], many city leaders were pushing for the region to become more "major league" suggesting that Mr. Rooney use his influence in the sports industry to have the league award Pittsburgh a franchise. Rooney proved his worth and from 1967 until the early 1970s was a part owner of the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]].{{cite web|url=http://pittsburghhockey.net/old-site/PensPages/66-69ERA/67Expansion.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510131830/http://pittsburghhockey.net/old-site/PensPages/66-69ERA/67Expansion.html |archivedate=2012-05-10 }}{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yS1UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QjoNAAAAIBAJ&dq=pittsburgh%20mcgregor&pg=7126,3658716 |title=Lawrence Journal-World – Google News Archive Search |publisher=}} ==Homestead Grays== In a 1981 interview by the ''[[Pittsburgh Press]]'' Rooney related that "from time to time he had helped financially support the Negro League team, the [[Homestead Grays]], and . . . was a better baseball fan than football fan."{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KKkcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=e2MEAAAAIBAJ&dq=art%20rooney&pg=4092,6282476 |title=The Pittsburgh Press – Google News Archive Search |publisher=}} ==Track sports== Rooney also acquired the [[Yonkers Raceway]] in 1972, the Palm Beach Kennel Club, Green Mountain Kennel Club in Vermont, Shamrock Stables in Maryland and owned the [[Liberty Bell Park Racetrack]] outside Philadelphia.{{cite news |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/sports/steelers/from-the-pg-archives-steelers-art-rooney-in-retrospect-506028/#ixzz2cJNb9100 |work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |first=Gary |last=Tuma |title=From the PG Archives: Steelers' Art Rooney in retrospect |date=October 14, 2007}} ==Later life== Following the [[AFL–NFL merger]] in 1970, the Steelers agreed to leave the NFL Eastern Conference and joined the AFC Central Division. {{Quote box | quote = Everyone knew Mr. Rooney was our number one citizen...he did more for this city than [[Richard King Mellon|R.K. Mellon]] did for the business community and [[David L. Lawrence|David Lawrence]] and any of the mayors who followed him, including [[Richard Caliguiri]], did politically. | source = [[Tom Foerster]]{{cite web |url=http://www.pittsburghsteelers.co.uk/steelers/rooneys/page1.htm |title=Art Rooney |publisher=}} | width = 31em | salign =right | quoted = 1 | title_bg = gray | title_fnt = white | bgcolor = lightgray }} Through expert scouting, the Steelers became a power. In 1972, they began a remarkable 8–year run of playoff appearances, and thirteen straight years of winning seasons, including three additional playoff berths. In Rooney's 41st season as owner, the club won the [[Super Bowl]]. During Rooney's lifetime the team also had [[Super Bowl]] victories following the 1975, 1978 and 1979 seasons. They also won the Super Bowl in the 2005 and 2008 seasons, making the Steelers the first team following the AFL–NFL merger to win six Super Bowls. {{Quote box | quote = I'll never forget the way he introduced me, 'This is Ralph Giampaolo, a member of our organization.' Not a member of our ground crew. Not some rinky-dink bum. But a member of 'our organization'. As far as [[Curt Gowdy|[Curt] Gowdy]] knew, I was vice president of the team. Mr. Rooney made me feel 10 feet tall. | source = Inviting a groundskeeper up to the owner's box for dinner. | width = 31em | salign =right | quoted = 1 | title_bg = gray | title_fnt = white | bgcolor = lightgray }} Following the Steelers' victory in [[Super Bowl IX]], Rooney stepped down from day-to-day management of the team, but remained the ultimate source of authority until his death. [[Dan Rooney|Dan]], his son, took over as team president. Rooney died from complications of a stroke on August 25, 1988. An August 1987 ''Pittsburgh Press'' story stated that Rooney never missed a Hall of Fame induction ceremony in all 25 years, and that he was asked to present his third inductee, [[John Henry Johnson]] that month.{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LKkcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OWMEAAAAIBAJ&dq=rooney%20hall%20of%20fame&pg=6978,412908 |title=The Pittsburgh Press – Google News Archive Search |publisher=}} In memory of "The Chief", Steelers wore a patch on the left shoulder of their uniforms with Rooney's initials '''AJR''' for the entire season. The team [[1988 Pittsburgh Steelers season|ended up finishing 5-11]], their worst record since a 1–13 showing in [[1969 Pittsburgh Steelers season|1969]]. He is buried at the [[North Side (Pittsburgh)|North Side]] Catholic [[Cemetery]] in Pittsburgh.[http://old.post-gazette.com/Steelers/19980830chief3.asp ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''] ==Legacy== [[File:Art Rooney Statute at HeinzField.JPG|thumb|left|A statue of Art Rooney at [[Heinz Field]]]] In 1964, he was elected to the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]]. [[Duquesne University]] named their football field in his honor in 1993. In 1999 Rooney ranked 81st on the ''[[Sporting News]]''' "100 Most Powerful Sports Figures of the 20th Century" list. A statue of his likeness graces the entrance to the home of the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], [[Heinz Field]]. The street that runs adjacent to Heinz Field on Pittsburgh's North Side is named "Art Rooney Avenue" in his honor.{{cite web |title=Map of Art Rooney Avenue |url=https://maps.google.com/maps?q=art+rooney+avenue+pittsburgh+pa&hl=en&ll=40.447098,-80.014163&spn=0.00307,0.004056&hnear=Art+Rooney+Ave,+Pittsburgh,+Pennsylvania&gl=us&sqi=2&t=h&z=18&vpsrc=6 |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=December 16, 2011}}{{cite news |last=Barnes |first=Tom |title=There has been development near the new stadiums, but no one is sure what will happen between them |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/steelers/20010824hdevelop0824P.asp |accessdate=December 16, 2011 |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |date=August 1, 2001 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63yxoR5WQ?url=http://www.post-gazette.com/steelers/20010824hdevelop0824P.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }} In 2000, he was inducted as a "pioneer" into the American Football Association's Semi-Pro Football Hall of Fame.{{cite web |title=2010 Hall of Fame listing |url=http://americanfootballassn.com/forms/2010HallofFameListing.pdf |publisher=americanfootballassn.com/ American Football Association |accessdate=December 16, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63yyR3crb?url=http://americanfootballassn.com/forms/2010HallofFameListing.pdf |archivedate=December 16, 2011 |format=PDF |deadurl=no |df= }} During Rooney's life, the Steelers would often use a late-round draft pick on a player from a local college like [[Pittsburgh Panthers football|Pitt]], [[West Virginia Mountaineers football|West Virginia]] or [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]]. Though these players rarely made the team, this practice was intended to appeal to local fans and players. The team has occasionally employed this practice after Rooney's death, however, they now focus more on talent than geography throughout the entire draft. Rooney also supposedly liked players from [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] due to his [[Irish Catholic]] background, which some say explains why he allegedly had the team keep Notre Dame alumnus and wounded [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]] veteran [[Rocky Bleier]].{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} Bleier would go on to become one of the key members of the team's success in the 1970s.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} {{Quote box | quote =Art Rooney is the finest person I've ever known. | source =— [[U.S. Supreme Court]] Justice [[Byron White]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/08/26/sports/sports-of-the-times-art-rooney-never-changed.html |title=Art Rooney Never Changed |date=26 August 1988 |work=The New York Times}} | width = 31em | salign =right | title = | quoted = 1 | title_bg = gray | title_fnt = white | bgcolor = lightgray }} {{Quote box | quote =[The] most popular sports figure in history. | source =— [[Art Modell]].{{cite web |url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-08-26/sports/26257120_1_instant-replay-art-rooney-owner |title=Archives – Philly.com |publisher=}} | width = 31em | salign =right | title = | quoted = 1 | title_bg = gray | title_fnt = white | bgcolor = lightgray }} Art Rooney is the subject of, and the only character in, the one-man play ''[[The Chief (play)|The Chief]]'', written by Gene Collier and Rob Zellers. The play debuted at the [[Pittsburgh Public Theater]] in 2003, and has been revived on three occasions since then. All productions have starred [[Tom Atkins (actor)|Tom Atkins]] as Rooney.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} At Steelers games, there is a sign that shows a picture of Rooney with his characteristic cigar and under the photo, the word "Believe."{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} {{Quote box | quote =My father always used to tell us boys, "Treat everybody the way you'd like to be treated. Give them the benefit of the doubt. But never let anyone mistake kindness for weakness." He took the Golden Rule and put a little bit of the North Side in it. | source =— Art Rooney Jr. on his father{{cite book |last=Mendelson |first=Abby |title=The Pittsburgh Steelers: The Official Team History |year=1996 |publisher=[[Taylor Trade Publishing]] |isbn=978-0-87833-957-0 |pages=1}} | width = 31em | salign =right | title = Art Rooney's North Side Golden Rule | quoted = 1 | title_bg = gray | title_fnt = white | bgcolor = lightgray }} Art J. Rooney was for 51 years, until her 1982 death, married to Kathleen Rooney née McNulty (1904–1982). Kathleen was the mother of Art's five sons, who are [[Dan Rooney]], the chairman of the board of directors of the Pittsburgh Steelers and a former [[United States Ambassador to Ireland]], Art Rooney Jr., Timothy Rooney, Patrick Rooney, and John Rooney (all also directors of the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]). She is also grandmother of the couple's 32 grandchildren, including current Steelers president [[Art Rooney II]] and [[U.S. Representative]] [[Thomas J. Rooney]] (R, FL-16). The couple also has about 75 great grandchildren, including actress sisters [[Kate Mara]] and [[Rooney Mara]].''The Scribner Encyclopedia of American Lives'', Vol. 2 (1986–1990), pp. 741-742, New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1999{{cite web |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/sports/steelers/the-rooneys-a-fight-for-future-generations-402075/ |title=The Rooneys: A fight for future generations |publisher=}}[https://www.nytimes.com/1988/08/26/obituaries/art-rooney-87-founder-nfl-s-steelers-dies.html?pagewanted=2 1988 NY Times obituary for Art Rooney]{{cite news |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/celebritology/2010/08/the_girl_with_the_dragon_tatto.html |work=The Washington Post |title='The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo' is … Rooney Mara}} ==References== '''General''' * {{cite web |last=Klavon |first=Jacqueline E. |title=Rooney, Arthur Joseph (The Chief) bio |url=http://www.pabook.libraries.psu.edu/palitmap/bios/Rooney__Art.html |work=Pennsylvania Center for the Book |accessdate=May 4, 2011}} '''Specific''' {{reflist|colwidth=40em}} {{Portal|Pittsburgh}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=O'Brien |first=Jim |title=The Chief: Art Rooney and his Pittsburgh Steelers |year=2001 |publisher=James P. O'Brien – Publishing |location=Pittsburgh |isbn=1-886348-06-5}} ==External links== {{commonscatinline|Art Rooney (1901–1988)}} * {{Profootballhof|id=183|name=Art Rooney}} * {{Find a Grave|5723}} {{Pittsburgh Steelers}} {{Pittsburgh Steelers general manager navbox}} {{Pittsburgh Steelers owners navbox}} {{Pittsburgh Penguins}} {{1964 Football HOF}} {{Pro Football Hall of Fame members}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rooney, Art}} [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:Duquesne Dukes football players]] [[Category:Pittsburgh Lyceum (football) players]] [[Category:Pittsburgh Steelers owners]] [[Category:Pittsburgh Steelers executives]] [[Category:Steagles players and personnel]] [[Category:Pittsburgh Penguins owners]] [[Category:Wheeling Stogies players]] [[Category:National Football League team presidents]] [[Category:National Hockey League executives]] [[Category:National Hockey League owners]] [[Category:Pro Football Hall of Fame inductees]] [[Category:Georgetown University alumni]] [[Category:Rooney family]] [[Category:People from Allegheny County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Players of American football from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Burials in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Catholics from Pennsylvania]]

{{other people|Bashir Ahmad}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox MSP | honorific-prefix = | name = Bashir Ahmad ([[Urdu]]: {{Nastaliq|بشیراحمد}}) | honorific-suffix = | image = | imagesize = 150px | caption = | constituency_MP = [[Glasgow (Scottish Parliament electoral region)|Glasgow]] | parliament = Scottish | majority = | term_start = 3 May 2007 | term_end = 6 February 2009 | predecessor = | successor = [[Anne McLaughlin]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1940|2|12|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Amritsar]], [[British Raj|India]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2009|2|6|1940|2|12|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Glasgow]], Scotland | birthname = | nationality = | party = [[Scottish National Party]] | spouse = Naseem | relations = | children = 7 | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | cabinet = | committees = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Bashir Ahmad''' (12 February 1940 – 6 February 2009) was a successful businessman and a [[Scottish National Party]] politician. He made history when he was elected to the [[Scottish Parliament]] to represent the [[Glasgow (Scottish Parliament electoral region)|Glasgow region]] at the [[Scottish Parliament election, 2007|2007 election]], as the first [[Member of the Scottish Parliament|MSP]] to be elected from [[Asian-Scots]], [[Mohammedan|Muslim]] and non-White backgrounds.<ref name="BBC News death">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/7876038.stm |title=Scotland's first Muslim MSP dies |work=[[BBC News]] |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
==Early life== Ahmad was born in [[Amritsar]], [[British India]] on 12 February 1940. In 1961, at the age of 21, he emigrated to Scotland from Pakistan.<ref name="Scotsman interview July 2007">{{cite news |url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/keeping-the-faith-1-907247 |title=Keeping the Faith |first=Jim |last=Gilchrist |work=[[The Scotsman]] |date=2 July 2007 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref> He served five terms as President of the Pakistan Welfare Association.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/5133456.stm|title=Scotland set for first Asian MSP |work=BBC News |date=30 June 2006 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
==Political career==
[[Image:Scottish Parliament flags half-staff.jpg|thumb|Flags outside of the Scottish Parliament flying at half-mast following the death of Bashir Ahmad MSP]]
Ahmnad joined the SNP in 1992. In 1995, he founded [[Asian Scots for Independence]] to attract more [[Asian-Scots]] to the party. When Bashir launched Scots Asians for Independence at the SNP conference in 1995, he gave a speech saying "it isn't important where you come from, what matters is where we are going together as a nation"<ref name="scotsman obituary">{{cite news|last=Davison |first=Phil |url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/bashir-ahmad-1-828488 |title=Bashir Ahmad |work=The Scotsman |date= 10 February 2009|accessdate=6 June 2018 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref>
He retired from business in 2003 to devote himself to [[Politics of Scotland|politics]]. In [[Glasgow City Council election, 2003]], he defeated Labour to become the Councillor for the Pollokshields East ward.
Upon his selection as second on the SNP's Glasgow list, Ahmad said: "The lack of any Asian or ethnic minority voice in the Scottish Parliament has been felt deeply in my community. But SNP members have righted that wrong. By doing so, they have proved that the SNP aspires to lead a Scottish Parliament that will represent all of Scotland – a truly national parliament. I firmly believe the SNP can now earn the trust of the Asian community throughout Scotland and that this will be a bond that endures for generations."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12772876.Society__The_race_for_Holyrood/ |title=Society: The race for Holyrood |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] |date=26 March 2007|accessdate=6 June 2018 |location=Glasgow}}</ref>
During the [[Scottish Parliament election, 2007|2007 elections]], Ahmad was elected to the [[Scottish Parliament]] on the Glasgow regional list. He thus became the first non-white and first Muslim [[Member of the Scottish Parliament|MSP]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/6622915.stm |title=First Asian MSP goes to Holyrood |work=BBC News |date=4 May 2007 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref><ref>[http://www.iwitness.co.uk/scottish/0706s-01.htm] Interview with The iWitness, Scotland's Muslim Newspaper</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/6622865.stm] BBC election report, Friday, 4 May 2007</ref> On the opening day of the [[3rd Scottish Parliament]], he wore traditional Pakistani clothing and took his oath of office using both the [[Urdu]] and [[English language]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/6638173.stm |title=MSPs at their best for ceremony |first=Andrew |last=Black |work=BBC News |date=9 May 2007 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/6637097.stm |title=New members sworn in at Holyrood |work=BBC News |date=9 May 2007 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
Ahmad lead the bill on making [[forced marriage]]s a criminal offence in Scotland and participated in a humanitarian campaign for Scottish hospitals to treat the most serious casualties of [[Israel]]'s attacks on the [[Gaza Strip]], particularly women and children with life-threatening burns or other wounds.<ref name="scotsman obituary"/> He was a member of the Scottish Parliament's [[Public Petitions Committee]], which decides which action should be taken on petitions submitted by individuals, groups or organisations.<ref name="scotsman obituary"/>
Ahmad died of a heart attack on 6 February 2009 at the age of 68.<ref name="BBC News death"/> His funeral was held at the [[Glasgow Central Mosque]] and he was buried in [[Cathcart Cemetery]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/politicians-pay-respects-at-funeral-of-msp-ahmad-1-1303875 |title=Politicians pay respects at funeral of MSP Ahmad |first1=Lucinda |last1=Cameron |first2=Sam |last2=Reeves |work=[[Scotland on Sunday]] |date=7 February 2009 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
==Family life== Bashir is survived by his wife Naseem, their five daughters, two sons and 11 grandchildren.<ref name="independent obituary">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/bashir-ahmad-the-scottish-parliaments-first-asian-member-1609209.html |title=Bashir Ahmad: The Scottish Parliament's first Asian member |work=[[The Independent]] |date= 14 February 2009|accessdate=6 June 2018 | location=London | first1=Alex | last1=Salmond | authorlink=Alex Salmond}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Pollokshields]]

{{Distinguish|BILANZ}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Bilan | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = Myret Zaki | editor_title = Editor-in-chief | frequency = Biweekly | circulation = 11,448 (2014) | category = Business magazine | company = [[Tamedia Group]] | publisher =Tamedia Publications | founded = | firstdate = {{start date and age|df=y|1989|6|1}} | finaldate = | country = [[Switzerland]] | based = [[Geneva]] | language =[[French language|French]] | website = [http://www.bilan.ch/ ''Bilan''] | issn = | oclc = }}
'''''Bilan''''' is a French language biweekly [[Business journalism|business magazine]] published in Geneva, [[Switzerland]].
==History and profile== ''Bilan'' was first published in June 1989.<ref name=peter6>{{cite web|author1=Thomas Häussler|author2=Peter Meier|title=Ringier's expansion to Eastern Europe in the 1990s|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/iehc2006/papers2/Haussler.pdf|publisher=Institute of Communication and Media Studies|accessdate=4 February 2015|location=Berne|format=Conference paper|date=2006}}</ref><ref name=tam>{{cite web|title=Bilan|url=http://www.tamedia.ch/en/media/media/bilan/|publisher=Tamedia AG|accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref> The publisher of the magazine was Alain Fabarez.<ref name=peter6/> It was owned by the [[Edipresse Group]]<ref>{{cite journal|author=Jany Lesseur|title=Can Papers Net a Profit?|journal=UNESCO Courier|date=January 1999|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-54237616/can-papers-net-a-profit|accessdate=26 December 2014}}{{Subscription required|via=Questia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=A planned merger of French- and German-language media groups|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/merger-to-alter-media-landscape/1001328|accessdate=25 December 2014|work=Swiss Info|date=4 March 2009}}</ref> until November 2011.<ref name=bberg>{{cite news|title=Tamedia acquires Bilan and Tribune des Arts|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/article/2011-11-07/a1NXDuhy98v8.html|accessdate=25 December 2014|work=Bloomberg|date=7 November 2011}}</ref> Then it became part of the [[Tamedia Group]].<ref name=tam/><ref name=bpress/><ref>{{cite news|author1=Markus Knöpfli|title=Die Bilanz geht in die Welt|url=http://medienwoche.ch/2014/05/02/die-bilanz-geht-in-die-welt/|accessdate=30 April 2015|work=Medien Woche|date=2 May 2014|language=German}}</ref> The magazine is published by Tamedia Publications biweekly on Wednesdays and has its headquarters in [[Geneva]].<ref name=tam/><ref>{{cite web|title=Bilan|url=http://www.publicitas.com/du/home/media-solutions/media-search/advanced-media-search/media-factsheet-detail/mediadata/bilan/?PARAM1=EK9BL1#.VJxPPcAgEc|work=Publicitas|accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref> It was published on a monthly basis until 2005 when its frequency was switched to biweekly.<ref name=peter6/><ref name=Usa/> Its headquarters was formerly in [[Lausanne]].<ref name="Usa">{{cite book|title=Switzerland Starting Business (Incorporating) in Switzerland Guide Strategic and Practical Information|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=akUVxX_87EsC&pg=PA236|accessdate=13 April 2015|publisher=Int'l Business Publications|isbn=978-0-7397-1688-5|page=237}}</ref>
''Bilan'' is the French counterpart of the Swiss [[German language|German]] business magazine, ''[[BILANZ]]''.<ref name=peter6/> ''Bilan'' features analyses of finance markets and targets managers of small or large enterprises and decision makers.<ref name=bpress>{{cite web|title=Bilan |url=http://www.business-press.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=247&Itemid=41 |work=Business Press |accessdate=25 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225201205/http://www.business-press.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=247&Itemid=41 |archivedate=25 December 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=p1>{{cite news|title=Bilan celebrates its 25th anniversary|url=http://www.publicitas.com/du/home/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=114426&title=switzerland-bilan-celebrates-its-25th-anniversary#.VJxOJsAgEc|accessdate=25 December 2014|work=Publicitas|date=2 June 2014}}</ref> It publishes several listings, including the 300 richest Switzerland, the 100 richest in Europe, the 300 most influential Switzerland, the 50 start-up invest in and the top 30 employers.<ref name=p1/> The biweekly also publishes interviews.<ref>{{cite news|author=Kaylen Gastrow|title=Uzbek Princess Not Investigated|url=http://www.litterareport.com/_stdd458505749b2941217ddd59394240e8|accessdate=25 December 2014|work=Littera Report|date=9 April 2013|location=Tashkent}}</ref>
Max Mabillard is one of the former [[editors-in-chief]] of ''Bilan''.<ref name=Usa/> Stéphane Benoit-Godet served as the editor-in-chief<ref name=bpress/> until 1 November 2014 when Myret Zaki was appointed to the post.<ref name=tam/><ref>{{cite news|title=Bilan - Nomination de Myret Zaki, nouvelle rédactrice en chef de Bilan|url=http://www.publicitas.com/du/home/media-solutions/all-promotions/promotion/detail/suisse-bilan-nomination-de-myret-zaki-nouvelle-redactrice-en-chef-de-bilan-476/#.VJxKDMAgEc|accessdate=25 December 2014|work=Publicitas|date=4 November 2014}}</ref>
==Circulation== The circulation of ''Bilan'' was 15,000 copies during its initial period.<ref name=peter6/> Between July 2004 and June 2005 the magazine had a circulation of 18,569 copies.<ref name=adn8>{{cite web|title=New circulation figures from July 2007 to June 2008|url=http://www.adnative.net/en/global/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=24771&title=switzerland-new-circulation-figures-from-july-2007-to-june-2008#.VR4t4ZSsXRA|work=Adnative|accessdate=3 April 2015|date=1 October 2008}}</ref> It was 18,703 copies between July 2005 and June 2006 and 19,047 copies between July 2006 and June 2007.<ref name=adn8/> Its circulation became 19,325 copies between July 2007 and June 2008.<ref name=adn8/> In 2011 the magazine had a circulation of 13,111 copies.<ref name=bberg/><ref name=bpress/> The circulation of the biweekly was 11,448 copies in 2014.<ref name=tam/>
==See also== * [[List of magazines in Switzerland]]
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
==External links== * [http://www.bilan.ch/ Official website]
{{Press in French-speaking Switzerland}} {{Portal bar|Journalism|Business and economics|Switzerland}}

{{Other uses|Business Today (disambiguation){{!}}Business Today}} {{Infobox Magazine | title = Business Today | image_file = | image_size = 150px | image_caption = Cover of Business Today's 40th Anniversary Issue | editor = Nicole Zivkovic | editor_title = President | previous_editor = Paul Kigawa | staff_writer = | frequency = Bi-Annual | circulation = 250,000 | company = Foundation for Student Communications, Inc. | publisher = | founded = 1968 | firstdate = | country = United States | based = [[Princeton University]] | language = English | website = [http://www.businesstoday.org businesstoday.org] | issn = }}
'''''Business Today''''' is an American, [[non-profit]] student organization that seeks to bridge the communication gap between college students and business executives. The organization publishes a magazine and hosts three national conferences: the International Conference, the Her Ventures Conference and the Designation Conference.
''Business Today'' is headquartered in [[Princeton, New Jersey]], and run by [[Princeton University]] undergraduates.<ref>[https://www.princeton.edu/odus/activities/organizations/directory/ Princeton University student groups listing]</ref> The organization has 15 student officers who commit their time to running the logistics, programs and new strategic initiatives. Past Business Today alumni sit on the company's Board of Trustees to provide guidance.
==Business Today Magazine== ''Business Today'' is an American magazine created by and for college students. It was founded in 1968 by three students at [[Princeton University]]—Jonathan Perel, [[Steve Forbes]], and Michael Mims. Currently, ''Business Today'' is the largest student-run magazine in the United States. It is published twice a year, and has a distribution base of over 200,000 college students and business executives.<ref>[http://www.ulm.edu/lyceum/forbes.html ULM Presidential Lyceum Series]</ref>
==International Conference== Founded in 1974, the Business Today International Conference is the organization's largest and signature event. The conference brings 150 distinguished undergraduate students from around the world together with current business and world leaders to discuss and share perspectives on relevant business issues. Past keynote speakers at the conference have included [[Gerald Ford]], [[Andrea Jung]], and [[Henry Kissinger]].
In 2017, the 43rd Annual International Conference attracted over 2000 applications and the conference itself focused on the theme of Redefining Innovation. Speakers included [[Brad Smith (American lawyer) | Brad Smith]], President of Microsoft,
It is the largest conference of its kind in the United States.<ref>[http://www.maryvillecollege.edu/news/news.asp?id=1336&pgID=1354 "Maryville College Junior Participates in Prestigious Business Today Conference" by Karen B. Eldridge, Maryville College, December 5, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218023650/http://www.maryvillecollege.edu/news/news.asp?id=1336&pgID=1354 |date=February 18, 2009 }}</ref>
==Aspire Conference For Women in Business==
==Designation Conference==
==Former members== *[[Steve Forbes]] - Editor-in-Chief of ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine *[[Wendy Kopp]] - Founder of [[Teach for America]] *[[Meg Whitman]] - President and CEO of [[Hewlett-Packard]]; formerly [[Ebay]] *[[Heather Maclean (author)|Heather Maclean]] - Author and Founder of [[Little Laureate]] *[[Michael Kratsios]] - Deputy Assistant to the President and Deputy US Chief Technology Officer * J. Christopher Donahue - President and CEO of [[Federated Investors]] * A.J. Agarwal - Managing Director at the [[Blackstone Group]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.businesstoday.org ''Business Today''] *[http://www.businesstoday.org/conferences ''Business Today'' International Conference]

A '''consultant''' (from {{lang-la|consultare}} "to discuss") is a [[professional]] who provides professional or expert advice<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/consultant |title=Consultant | Define Consultant at Dictionary.com |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com |date=2004-03-09 |accessdate=2014-07-20}}</ref> in a particular area such as security ([[information security|electronic]] or [[physical security|physical]]), [[management]], [[accountancy]], [[law]], [[human resources]], [[marketing]] (and [[public relations]]), [[finance]], [[engineering]], [[science]] or any of many other specialized fields.
A consultant is usually an expert or a professional in a specific field and has a wide knowledge of the subject matter.<ref>Pieter P. Tordoir (1995). ''The professional knowledge economy: the management and integration services in business organizations.'' p.140.</ref> The role of consultant outside the medical sphere (where the term is used specifically for a grade of doctor) can fall under one of two general categories: * Internal consultant – someone who operates within an organization but is available to be consulted on areas of specialism by other departments or individuals (acting as clients); or * External consultant – someone who is employed externally (either by a firm or some other agency) whose expertise is provided on a temporary basis, usually for a fee. As such this type of consultant generally engages with multiple and changing clients.
The overall impact of a consultant is that clients have access to deeper levels of expertise than would be feasible for them to retain in-house, and may purchase only as much service from the outside consultant as desired.
== Qualifications == {{unreferenced-section|date=March 2017}} Consultant [[Peter Block]] defines a consultant as "someone who has influence over an individual, group, or organization, but who has no direct authority to implement changes." He contrasts this with a ''surrogate manager'' who is a person who "acts on behalf of, or in place of, a manager." The key difference is that a consultant never makes decisions for the individual or group, whereas a surrogate manager does make decisions.
Accredited Associates are bound by a [[Code of Ethics]] that requires the consultant to only provide “practical advice that works” — by “Analysing as a Generalist and Solving as a Specialist” — using the skills and experience of a sub-contracted fellow Associate, thus at all times providing the client with the best available advice and support.
There is no single qualification to be a consultant other than those laid down in relation to medical & engineering personnel who have attained this level-degree in it.
Internationally the accreditation of Management Consultants is overseen by higher education training and accreditation organizations.
The International Council of Management Consulting Institutes (ICMCI) was founded in 1987 and has around 50 member institutes covering the globe. The award of [[Certified management consultant|Certified Management Consultant (CMC)]] status is its internationally recognized accreditation (in some countries like the US, conforms to ISO/IEC 17024:2003 standards) that is not specific to the technical content of the consultant's practice. For instance this could be held equally by a [[Human resources|Human Resources (HR)]] expert or a [[chemical engineer]] operating as management consultants in their field(s) of expertise. There are about 10,000 CMCs worldwide.
Chartered Institute of Management Consultants (CIMC) is a not-for-profit professional body chartered federally under Letters Patent granted by the Government of Canada. CIMC is also chartered under the Laws of the State of Delaware, USA. CIMC is also registered with the National Certification Commission, USA. The CIMC award Chartered Management Consultant Ch.MC designation as a global management credential.
[[International Federation of Consulting Engineers]] (FIDIC) is a Federation whose members are national associations of Consulting Engineers.
== See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ;Related concepts * [[Adviser]] * [[Contingent workforce]] * [[Independent contractor]] * [[Interim management]] * [[IRS reclassification]] * [[Permatemp]] * [[Tax advisor]] {{Col-break}} ;Types of consulting/consultant * [[Biotechnology consulting]] * [[Consultant (medicine)]] * [[Consultant pharmacist]] * [[Creative consultant]] * [[Consulting psychology]] * [[Economic consulting]] * [[Educational consultant]] * [[Employment consultant]] * [[Environmental consultant]] * [[Foreclosure consultant]] * [[Human resource consulting]] * [[Image consultant]] {{Col-break}} ;Types of consultant (more) * [[Immigration consultant]] * [[Information technology consulting]] * [[Legal nurse consultant]] * [[Loss control consultant]] * [[Management consulting]] * [[Market entry consultant]] * [[Media consultant]] * [[Performance consulting]] * [[Political consulting]] * [[Public consultation]] * [[Process consultant]] * [[Statistical consultant]] {{col-end}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox building | name = Chrysler House | image = DimeBuildingDetroit.jpg | location = 719 [[Griswold Street]]
[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | alternate_names = Griswold Place
Dime Savings Bank Building
Commonwealth Building | coordinates = {{coord|42.331063|-83.04832|region:US-MI_type:landmark|display=it}} | completion_date = 1912 | renovation_date = 2002 | building_type = Commercial offices | roof = {{convert|99|m|abbr=on}} | top_floor = | floor_count = 23 | elevator_count = | cost = | floor_area = | structural_engineer= | main_contractor = | developer = | owner = | management = | architect = [[Daniel Burnham]] | ren_architect = Barton Malow | nrhp = {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | nrhp_type = cp | nocat = yes | partof = Detroit Financial District | partof_refnum = 09001067 | locmapin = Michigan | architecture = [[Neoclassical architecture|Neo-Classical]] | designated_nrhp_type = December 14, 2009 | governing_body = Private }} | references = {{emporis|118495}}{{skyscraperpage|8871}}{{structurae|s0027683}} }} '''Chrysler House''' is a 23-story, {{convert|99|m|abbr=on}} [[skyscraper]] located at 719 Griswold Street in [[Downtown Detroit|Downtown]] [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. The [[Class A office|class-A office building]] is adjacent to the [[Penobscot Building]] in the heart of the U.S. designated [[Detroit Financial District]]. It is used as an [[office building]], with [[retail]] space on the street level. ==History== The building was constructed between 1910 and 1912[http://historicdetroit.org/building/dime-building/ Dime Building]. ''Historic Detroit''. Retrieved on April 21, 2016. and known for many years as the '''Dime Building'''. When completed, the tower was named the Dime Savings Bank Building for its primary tenant. It was later renamed the Commonwealth Building, briefly known as Griswold Place. It became the Dime Building again in 2002, before being renamed in 2012. The original [[Lincoln Highway|Lincoln Highway Association]] national headquarters occupied office 2115 on the 21st floor from 1913 to 1928. For several years through 1983, the building housed the headquarters of Bank of the Commonwealth until the bank merged with [[Comerica]]. In 2002, a $40-million renovation was completed.[http://detroithistorical.org/learn/encyclopedia-of-detroit/dime-building Dime Building]. ''Detroit Historical Society''. Retrieved on April 21, 2016. In August 2011, [[Quicken Loans]] founder [[Dan Gilbert (businessman)|Dan Gilbert]] purchased the building along with the nearby [[The Qube (Detroit)|Qube]], [[First National Building]] and [[Wright-Kay Building]].{{cite news| title=Dan Gilbert scoops up three more downtown Detroit buildings, fourth on the way| date=27 December 2011| author=Michael Wayland| url=http://www.mlive.com/business/detroit/index.ssf/2011/12/dan_gilbert_scoops_up_three_mo.html| work=[[Grand Rapids Press]]| publisher=mlive.com| accessdate=2012-04-25}} On April 30, 2012, Gilbert and [[Chrysler Group LLC]] chairman [[Sergio Marchionne]] announced that Chrysler will move its Great Lakes Business Center and some executive offices, with approximately 70 employees, into the two top floors of the building. As part of the lease, the building was renamed for the company.{{cite news| title=Chrysler's Dime Building Move A Strong Symbol Of Detroit Commitment| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-kiley/chrysler-dime-building-detroit-chrysler-house_b_1464466.html?ref=business| publisher=[[Huffington Post]]| author=David Kiley| date=30 April 2012| accessdate=2012-04-30}} ==Architecture== The tower was designed in the [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical architectural style]] by [[Daniel Burnham]].{{Cite book | author=Hill, Eric J. and John Gallagher | title=AIA Detroit: The American Institute of Architects Guide to Detroit Architecture | year=2002 | publisher=Wayne State University Press | isbn=0-8143-3120-3}} P. 90.{{Cite book | author= Sharoff, Robert | title=American City: Detroit Architecture, 1845-2005| publisher=Wayne State University Press| year=2005| isbn=0-8143-3270-6| authorlink= Robert Sharoff}} P. 25. The steel-framed structure is faced with white glazed brick and terra cotta trim. The most distinctive feature is the central light court which begins on the third floor and creates a U-shaped floor plan on the upper office floors. This feature can be seen in an earlier version on Burnham's Miner's National Bank Building, now Citizens Bank financial Center, completed one year earlier in downtown [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]]. Miner's National Bank is a similar, but smaller-scale design with the main banking hall in the space below the light court and featuring a large skylight. A later expansion of the building altered the U-shape of the upper floors.{{cite web| title=Citizens Bank Financial Center| url=http://www.emporis.com/building/citizensbankfinancialcenter-wilkesbarre-pa-usa| work=Emporis | accessdate=2013-03-29}} In a subsequent renovation, the lower two floors were refaced with gray granite and a pediment above the central entrance and cornice were removed. ==Gallery== File:Dime Building construction.jpg|Construction of the Dime Building. August 31, 1912 File:Dime Building, 1912.jpg|Exterior. December 31, 1912 File:Dime Interior.jpg|Interior, c. 1912 File:Dime Savings Bank Building Detroit MI.jpg File:Penobscot.jpg|[[Penobscot Building]] left, with the Chrysler House ==See also== {{Portal|Metro Detroit|Architecture}} *[[List of tallest buildings in Detroit]] *[[Chrysler Headquarters and Technology Center]] *[[Sergio Marchionne]] {{commonscatinline|Dime Building}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite book| author=Moore, Charles| title=Daniel H. Burnham, Architect, Planner of Cities, Volume 2| year=1921| publisher=Houghton Mifflin|id=}} *Duggan, Daniel. "[http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20120430/FREE/120439996/dime-building-renamed-chrysler-house-as-automaker-moves-workers-into-space-in-downtown-detroit Dime Building renamed Chrysler House as automaker moves workers into space in downtown Detroit]." ''[[Crain's Detroit Business]]''. April 30, 2012. *Hoffman, Bryce G. "[http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20120924/AUTO0101/209240399 Chrysler opens Detroit office in former Dime Building]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}." ''[[Detroit News]]''. September 24, 2012. *Gallagher, John. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20121109110839/http://www.freep.com/article/20120430/BUSINESS06/120430017/Quicken-Loans-Chrysler-Dime-Building-ceremony Quicken Loans helps welcome Chrysler to historic new digs today]." ''[[Detroit Free Press]]''. April 30, 2012. *"[http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20120425/AUTO0101/204250385/1148/AUTO01/Marchionne-70-employees-moving-Detroit-s-Dime-Building Marchionne, 70 employees moving to Detroit's Dime Building]."{{dead link|date=November 2012}} ''[[The Detroit News]]''. {{Downtown Detroit}} {{Architecture of metropolitan Detroit}} {{Buildings in Michigan timeline}} {{National Register of Historic Places listings in Wayne County, Michigan}} [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Detroit]] [[Category:Downtown Detroit]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1912]] [[Category:Office buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Michigan]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Detroit]] [[Category:Historic district contributing properties in Michigan]] [[Category:Rock Ventures]] [[Category:1912 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:1910s architecture in the United States]]
